resource.chars:
Prof. Owen’s statement <s>that<\s> is that in Rhynchonella psittacea 
“The intestine, inclines to the right side 
and makes a slight bend forwards before 
perforating the circumscribing membrane 
in order to terminate between the mantle 
lobes on that side “ On the anat. of the Branchiopoda
p.152.
I find, on the contrary, that the intestine 
passes at first straight downwards in the 
middle line as in Waldheimia, but 
instead of terminating in a rounded 
<s>canal <\s> tapering extremity as in that genus, 
it bends upwards & then curves round 
to the <\u>left<\u> side forming a sort of free 
caecum in the visceral cavity -  My 
reasons for believing that it is a free caecum 
are these -: in the first place, no anal 
aperture can be detected in the mantle 
cavity either on the right or left sides,
although the small size of the animal
